content.title: Upper Extremity Deep Vein Thrombosis (UEDVT)
content.definition: Thrombosis of the deep veins of the upper extremity (axillary, subclavian, or brachiocephalic veins), representing 4-10% of all DVT. Classified as primary (effort-related or idiopathic) or secondary (catheter-related, malignancy, thoracic outlet compression).

key_concepts.description: Primary UEDVT: spontaneous or effort-related (Paget-Schroetter syndrome), idiopathic. Secondary UEDVT: catheter-related (most common), malignancy, thoracic outlet compression, pacemaker leads
4-10% of all DVT; increasing incidence due to more central venous catheters; secondary UEDVT more common than primary in hospitalized patients
Primary effort thrombosis in young, healthy individuals after vigorous arm activity; associated with thoracic outlet compression; requires decompression (first rib resection) to prevent recurrence
Most common cause of UEDVT (>80%); related to central venous catheters, PICC lines, pacemakers; may be asymptomatic; treatment often with catheter in place if still needed
Arm swelling, pain, erythema; distended superficial veins; heavy sensation; may have superior vena cava syndrome features if extends centrally; often asymptomatic with catheters
Pulmonary embolism (3-12%); post-thrombotic syndrome (less common than lower extremity); loss of venous access; superior vena cava syndrome; recurrence
Duplex ultrasound is first-line; may miss subclavian vein behind clavicle; CT venography or MR venography for central veins and thoracic outlet evaluation
Anticoagulation (heparin then warfarin/DOAC) for at least 3 months; catheter removal if no longer needed; if catheter needed, can treat with catheter in place
Thrombolysis (catheter-directed) for acute thrombosis → anticoagulation → first rib resection (2-4 weeks later) to decompress thoracic outlet and prevent recurrence
Unprovoked UEDVT (no catheter, no trauma) should prompt malignancy workup; thorough history/physical; age-appropriate cancer screening

learning_objectives: Classify UEDVT as primary vs secondary
Recognize catheter-related UEDVT as most common cause
Understand Paget-Schroetter requires thrombolysis + rib resection
Know to screen for malignancy in unprovoked UEDVT
clinical_pearls: Young athlete with arm DVT after activity = Paget-Schroetter
Can treat catheter-related UEDVT with line in place if still needed
PE rate 3-12% - lower than lower extremity DVT
Duplex may miss subclavian - use CT/MR venography if needed
common_mistakes: Treating Paget-Schroetter with anticoagulation alone (needs rib resection)
Not considering malignancy in unprovoked cases
Assuming benign course (PE and PTS still occur)
Removing necessary catheter when can treat with line in place
